Dead Cells is a 2d action roguelike, with incredibly tight controls and a huge variety of weaponry!
It has very beautiful pixelgraphics and animations, it simply looks amazing and the sounds are also top notch!

There are lots of secrets to uncover and many enemies and bosses to fight, as you go deeper and deeper into it and slowly but surely reach further and further each time!

Once you've got the hang of it, it comes with all kinds of additional difficulty changes, which really feels like the game just starts there. You get more/harder enemies and less health refills, but its incredibly satisfying to go through!

There are a few different permanent upgrades to get, which gives you the ability to unlock new paths, which lead to entirely different maps aswell. You can play ranged or melee builds, you can be offensive or defensive, you can be playing mostly using items aswell. There are many different ways and opportunities to try different builds!

Want to go glasscannon and shred through your enemies very quickly? Or do you want to play safe from ranged and take your time and throw down turrets and stuff? Its all possible, but as the items are random, you're never guaranteed the perfect build. You gotta play with what you get and thats making every run different and fun!

You will be addicted to this for quite some time, once you start! :D

Dead Cells is a brilliant mix of rogue-like and Metroidvania that delivers fast-paced combat, tight controls, and a beautifully detailed world. The variety of weapons and abilities keeps things fresh as you experiment with different playstyles on every run. However, the game's permadeath mechanic—where you have to start from the beginning each time you die—can feel repetitive and even grindy after a while. While it's undeniably addictive and rewarding, the constant reset after death may dampen the momentum for players who prefer progression over repetition. Still, the game's challenge, fluidity, and replayability make it a standout experience in the genre.

The game presents us with an important choice, but we shouldn't really worry too much about our answer. It doesn't matter if we like the result of our first decision between bow or shield or not, because we'll repeat it every time we start over, and that's going to happen a lot in this world where we can die at any moment. What we still won't know after that first death is that the answer to that question contains the very gene that makes Dead Cells a different animal from the hundreds of 2D action sidescrollers that abound in excess today: the gene of constant choice. Pay attention to this game, lovers of classic challenges: Dead Cells is a new monster to beat.

I absolutely love this game. It's extremely challenging but equally rewarding. I'm obsessed with the blend of brutality, humor, stunning aesthetic, unique characters, and of COURSE the weapons. Oh my god, the variety of weapons is amazing. Would highly recommend if you're into a punishing game that keeps you coming back.

I first played Dead Cells on Game Pass.  Then I bought it.  I'm a fan of the Roguelike genre.  Not sure what it says about me if I enjoy dying over and over and over and over again.

There's something so satisfying in discovering that new item that lets you more further than ever before.  And then dying to some new critter.

As you progress you try to customize your build to best suit your needs.  What weapons have you got?  Do I boost damage or defense?  These thoughts are going through your head as you go through the 5Ds: Dodge, duck, dip, dive and dodge your way towards ... another death.

This is a great, fast action game.  It's one of those games that doesn't take a massive time commitment to play.  You can play 15-20 mins and put it down again.  A full run took me around 30-45mins.  I rarely made it though.  The weapons are fun and eventually you'll be hoping for your favorite.

If, like me, you enjoy death (specifically your own, and often) and carnage (some that is you but more that is the enemy) this is a fun game.  The first few times you play you might play a bit too long...

No bug or glitches for me.  Just some fairly addictive fun!

My favourite rouge-lite of all time. The combat in this game is 10/10, all the weapons are super unique and fun to use. Dead Cells is very very hard though. Early on in the game, at the end of each stage you'll get a full refill to your health and your flask (item you can use multiple times to top off your health in stages). Upon reaching higher difficulties, this health/flask refill is slowly stripped away from you, and at the highest difficulty, you can barely survive taking more than 2 hits per stage. You'll eventually have to basically do every stage taking 0-1 hits, it's very hard but also very fun.

Also, DON'T SPREAD OUT YOUR SCROLL STATS. Pick 1 colour, use only weapons/items of that colour and stack every scroll point you get into that colour. Damage gain from scroll stats is exponential, you need every point you can possibly get

Dead Cells is a thrilling, fast-paced roguelike platformer that brings a lot of excitement in every run. The combat is quick and snappy, with tight controls that feel satisfying to master. You collect "cells" to unlock various blueprints for weapons, items, and cosmetics, adding a lot of replay value as you experiment with different builds and combinations.

What sets this game apart is its accessibility to those short on time. Each run typically lasts about 30 minutes, making it an ideal choice for players who can only squeeze in short gaming sessions. Despite the game's relatively short runs, there’s a ton of content to explore. Multiple paths, challenging mobs, and punishing bosses keep you on your toes, but the sense of reward you get when you finally defeat a tough enemy is unmatched.

On top of that, the game’s sound design and music are top-tier, immersing you fully into the Dead Cells universe. The variety of unlockable gear, including weapons and cosmetics, gives you plenty of options to personalize your gameplay and keep things fresh.

Although it's a difficult game, it’s this challenge that makes the victory all the sweeter. If you’re someone who doesn’t have a lot of time for gaming but still wants something engaging, Dead Cells is the perfect fit. You can jump in for a quick session, have a blast, and feel like you’ve accomplished something in just a short burst. Truly one of my favorite games to unwind with!

Tight, addicting, fast-paced combat that's punishing if you don't keep up with its rhythm. Environments are very pretty but you often don't get too see much of it as most of the time you'll rather be blazing through the level trying to get to the end. Either that, or you've seen so much of it (roguelite, remember?) that all you can focus on is efficiency.

Efficiency. It's a fickle thing that the game demands for, but that efficiency can oftentimes be a detriment to your enjoyment of the game—efficiency in Dead Cells means going through the same specific set of biomes to get the most amount of cells and power scrolls possible, which leads to fighting the same bosses over and over again, choosing the same weapon and skills with the same stats, etc etc. The biome's enemies only have variety through different difficulties, often adding one or two new enemies with each new Boss Cell collected.

Doing the same thing over and over again, like many things, loses its charm. Even if you're winning.
That's me, 50 hours into the game.

Although I suppose this is more of a 'me' issue... it's the way I've been playing the game from 1BC all the way to 4BC. And yes, I've been stuck in 4BC for a while. The difficulty walls (specifically at 2BC and 4BC) are a bit frustrating and it's the reason why I haven't had the motivation to 'finish' the game properly, but I'll surely make it if I try hard enough... eventually.

Don't get me wrong though, the game IS fun, and offers a wide variety of weapons and skills for you to play with in three distinct categories which all have their own attack styles (more or less, I forgot the word for it). Brutality, hack-n-slash weapons that let you dice through enemies. Tactics, mostly ranged weapons that use an ammo system. Survival, slow but hard-hitting weapons that actually make you think about your move unlike Brutality (it's not shade at the weapons, it's shade at myself. I don't like Survival ;D)

I guess the one thing I don't like about the game is how vague the lore is. It reminds of Slay the Spire's lore—it's there, but not quite. You'll have to do quite a bit of digging to find things out yourself, if you even want to anyway.

It's definitely worth the price, bundled up with all of the DLC. Go get it. It's not 10/10 good, but it's damn near it.

I have so much fun playing Dead Cells on pc! I tried it before on xbox and didn't get very far; I'm so so glad that I decided to try it again on pc. The art is fantastic and the music a straight-up vibe. The beginning can be pretty tough, as with most games, but once you start gaining permanent changes it starts to flow better. This game can be so frustrating sometimes, but that's what makes successes all the more rewarding! I love that the map changes every time because it keeps it from feeling too stale when you have to start again. My one issue is that sometimes the map spawns a situation that prevents me from progressing any further. As best I can remember, this has only happened to me on the first level. When it does happen, I have to restart the run. I got some dlcs as well - they are well worth the upgrade. So far I've played through most of the Castlevania one and I enjoyed the art, setting, and the enemies they made for it. I'm not any kind of Castlevania fan, but playing the dlc made me want to get into it. To summarize: this game is hard yet rewarding as well as aesthetic and I highly recommend it.

New York styled Pizza:
Pizza dough:
14 g instant yeast
617g water - 95F
950g all-purpose flour
19g fine sea salt
25g granulated sugar
American Pizza Sauce and Toppings:
1 tablespoon (14g) butter
1 tablespoon (9g) extra virgin olive oil
6 cloves garlic, rough chopped
2 teaspoons (4g) red pepper flakes
28 oz (794g) can of crushed tomato
2 teaspoons (2g) dried oregano
1.5 tablespoons (21g) granulated sugar
salt and pepper to taste
Splash of olive oil
2 cups (227g) low moisture mozzarella, fresh grated
2 cups (200g) Monterey jack cheese, fresh grated
1/2 cup (26g) parmigiano reggiano, fresh grated
American Pizza Dough:
Preheat the oven and a baking steel or pizza stone at 500F for 45 minutes before utilizing it.
Whisk yeast and sugar into your water, and allow it to sit for 5 minutes. In a separate bowl, add flour and salt and mix by hand to combine. Pour your water mixture into your flour and mix by hand until you get a rough dough, then transfer to a work surface and knead until it starts to pull away from the work surface and is relatively smooth.
Place your dough in a greased bowl, then cover with plastic wrap and let rise for 1 - 2 hours at room temperature or until double in size.
Punch down your dough and dive into 300g pieces. Form those pieces into balls and place them in a floured proofing pizza box, cover with a lid, and proof at room temperature for 3 - 4 hours. (If you do not have a proofing pizza box, you can use a floured baking sheet, cover it with an inverted baking sheet and wrap it in plastic wrap.)
American Pizza Sauce and Toppings:
In a medium sauce pot, add butter and olive oil. Set that over medium-high heat; once the butter melts add garlic, cook until fragrant, add pepper flakes, and cook, stirring occasionally, until the garlic begins to brown on the edges.
Add crushed tomatoes, oregano, salt, and a splotch of olive oil, boil over medium-high, reduce heat to low, and simmer for 12 minutes, stirring occasionally or until thickened and viscous—season with salt to taste and let it cool down.
Assembly.- Place one of your pizza doughs onto a floured pizza peel, and flour your dough generously.
Punch your dough down in the center, working your way out to create a ¼” wide. Pick up your dough, place it over your closed fists, and rotate it around, gently stretching to 13” to 14”.
Place a couple of spoons of your sauce, starting in the center, spreading in little circles, and working your way to the edge until it gets evenly spread out.
In a medium-size mixing bowl, place mozzarella cheese, Monterey Jack, and Parmigiano; mix until combined. Sprinkle your cheese mixture to your desire and place in the oven onto your baking steel and bake for 5 - 7 minutes or until the edge gets golden brown and the cheese melts.
Enjoy.

As a dedicated player who has sunk several hundred hours into the mobile version of Dead Cells, I can confidently say that this game is a must-have for any gaming enthusiast. The seamless transition to mobile devices has only enhanced the already stellar gameplay experience, making Dead Cells a standout title in the mobile gaming landscape.

Dead Cells excels in blending challenging gameplay, intricate level design, and addictive progression systems that keep players coming back for more. The mobile version captures the essence of the original game, delivering a smooth and responsive experience that is a joy to play on the go.

The roguelike elements of Dead Cells, coupled with its procedurally generated levels, ensure that each run feels fresh and exciting, offering a high level of replayability that keeps me hooked for hours on end. The fast-paced combat, strategic decision-making, and rewarding exploration make every playthrough a thrilling adventure.

The mobile version of Dead Cells truly shines with its intuitive touch controls, optimized interface, and overall performance that rivals its console and PC counterparts. Whether I'm diving into a quick session during my commute or immersing myself in extended gameplay sessions at home, Dead Cells on mobile delivers a consistently enjoyable experience.

In conclusion, Dead Cells on mobile is a gem of a game that has kept me entertained for countless hours. Its blend of challenging gameplay, replay value, and mobile-friendly design make it a standout title that I wholeheartedly recommend to any mobile gamer looking for a rewarding and engaging experience. Don't miss out on the mobile version of Dead Cells - it's a true masterpiece that will keep you coming back for more.

Title: “Dead Cells: The Game That Loves to Watch You Suffer”

If you ever wanted a game that combines the thrill of a dungeon crawler with the emotional rollercoaster of a soap opera, Dead Cells is your ticket to a wild ride. Imagine if your favorite platformer and roguelike had a baby, and then that baby decided to grow up and become a professional torturer. That’s Dead Cells for you.

First off, let’s talk about the plot. Oh wait, there isn’t one! You’re a blob of cells that somehow got a body and now you’re running around an island prison, dying repeatedly. It’s like Groundhog Day, but with more spikes and fewer groundhogs.

The gameplay is where the real fun begins. You start off thinking, “Hey, this isn’t so bad,” as you slice through a few enemies. But then the game decides to remind you who’s boss. Suddenly, you’re surrounded by monsters, traps, and the occasional boss who looks like they just stepped out of your worst nightmare. And just when you think you’ve got the hang of it, you die. Again. And again. And again. It’s like the game is saying, “Oh, you thought you were good at this? That’s adorable.”

The graphics are beautiful, which is great because you’ll be seeing the same levels over and over again. The music is fantastic too, providing a lovely soundtrack to your repeated failures. And let’s not forget the weapons! There are so many to choose from, each one more useless than the last when you’re up against a boss with the reflexes of a caffeinated squirrel.

But the best part? The permadeath. Nothing says “fun” like losing all your progress because you got cocky and thought you could take on that elite enemy. It’s a humbling experience, really. You start to question your life choices. “Why did I think this was a good idea? Should I have just played something easier, like Dark Souls?”

In conclusion, Dead Cells is a fantastic game if you enjoy a challenge, beautiful graphics, and the sweet, sweet taste of defeat. It’s a game that will make you laugh, cry, and possibly throw your controller across the room. But hey, at least you’ll have fun doing it.

By far my favorite roguelike game I own. I've had so much fun replaying it. It's pretty easy to get the hang of and it's difficult sure, but just the perfect amount of difficult. There are some cool references from other games you might know in here too. I just love all the outfits you can unlock, along with the weapons that each have their own gimmicks. Another thing that needs to be mentioned are the playstyles. Whether it be a hack and slash melee build or a steady pace ranger build, there's a playstyle for everyone. I personally like to go with a full brutality build but there are so many options. I recommend using weapons that are able to stun enemies, since this was what helped me beat some of the harder bosses most of the time. The platforming aspect of the game isn't too hard either, and I should mention I'm extremely bad at platformers. This game also has many secrets which makes you have to carefully spot for on the screen, which was a very fun discovering them. It gets frustrating dying sometimes, but pushing through every run, you get further and further. Then you get a feeling of accomplishment after seeing the credits roll. Even after completing the game for the first time, it's not the end yet because now you're able to make the game more challenging to progress throughout the story and making the game adapt to your new strength. The lore of Dead Cells is pretty interesting and was something cool that I had to piece together each run. It is undeniably time consuming (I should know, I've stayed up many hours just to make a dent through progression of the game), but it's definitely worth the experience. I'll remember this game by the amount of times the beheaded has given somebody the middle finger. Overall it's 10/10 game, so get it and escape the dungeon, leaving no one in your path to stop you.

A brutal yet amazing game all around. It's a truly unique combination of metroidvania and roguelike and it excels at what it does. 

The game's system for stat progression allows players to choose a sort of identity for their run. Big and slow, fast and dangerous, or tactical and long-range? Within these categories there are dozens of different weapons to choose from, each drastically changing how the player approaches combat, causing each run to feel wildly different. The combat itself is on point, and I would call it hard to learn and hard to master. You start off getting hit by every other enemy, but a hundred runs later you'll be dashing through them like they're nothing. It's really fluid, feels great, and is really satisfying once you get the hang of it.

The art style is really pretty. It's 2D and pixelated, but the way that the moving parts are modeled give them a distinct 3D look. The music and sound effects are great and solidify the game's eerie apocalyptic atmosphere. There are tons of different areas to explore (with even more in all of the various dlcs, which are all worth the money) and a lot of different unlockable items and cosmetics that give the game hundreds of hours of playtime.

People who like roguelites will almost definitely enjoy this game. It's really hard, but if you stick with it, you'll have a blast.

Absolutely loved this game! This game features a vast amount of different routes to take on each run and various different weapon combos to use that make the game extremely fun to play. Even after so many runs through the levels I do not feel even remotely bored of this game yet. They also are constantly adding new content. 

Additionally, includes a lot of subtle lore and storytelling that I still am uncovering years later. Contains a lot of Easter eggs and funny references as well. I was initially worried about the Castlevania addition to the game, but it doesn't actually seem out of place. I loved Castlevania as a kid and getting to enjoy it in this game is a plus.

Also, as someone who has low vision, the ability to make the text bigger and have it not break the game is amazing (which Steam is notorious for being bad at). The game allows for in-depth customization to make the game easier to [play for people, for example- an option to change the font for those with dyslexia, and enemy highlighting to make them pop out more for low vision.

Saw people playing this game and thought I'd give it a shot since it was on sale. The aesthetic and pixel art is really cool. Love the art style, music, and unique animations for weapons. I've tried really hard to like this game, but gameplay-wise it's just not fun. 

Everything does so much damage. I'll get scroll after scroll and amulets that reduce damage but every mob, even the tiny cute ones, do at minimum 50% my health. I feel like I have to play absolutely flawlessly to progress.

Bosses are a frustrating clusterf*** . Thankfully, the devs put a training mode for bosses you encountered. Sounds great. Except every time you die in the training it kicks you back to the entrance to the training room and you have to backtrack all the way back to the boss you want to fight and restart. The devs should've known that people were going to be doing the training fights over and over, and not put all this waiting in between dying. 

With only the bosses being what kills me on a run, my gameplay style has remained unchanged. Instead of "learning from my mistakes" like a roguelike is supposed to be, Dead Cells is more just banging my head against a wall until I win. Not my definition of a good time.

Also, I love the amount of weapons in this game. Too bad I can only use less than a dozen. I understand they have to be unlocked, but it takes 2-3 runs, maybe more, to unlock one item/upgrade/cosmetic. Its a drag, and it doesn't even guarantee it will make future runs easier because I don't know what the weapons play like besides a vague description.

All in all I feel like getting better every run is just not happening, and permanent upgrades don't really do much to help.

The game's pretty good. It's easy to get into, as it is a typical roguelike with metroidvania features. The platforming isn't super tricky and isn't really the main focal point of the game. Rather, the charm of the experience comes with the various different builds you could make, some straight up breaking the game (won't spoil for obvious reasons). 

The learning curve is steep though. You could clear your first run in a matter of 10-20 hours. After you beat the final boss on each ascending difficulty though, you unlock a new boss cell which adds more of a challenge to your runs, should you want to have them activated. From there, the game stops being a snooze fest where you can one shot every enemy by just slam jumping, and you're forced to use your skill. 

Overall, 8/10. The lore is also real neat too.

Dead Cells is an absolute gem in the roguelike genre, offering a thrilling mix of fast-paced action, tight controls, and beautifully crafted environments. From the moment I started playing, I was hooked by its fluid combat and endless replayability.

The game's procedurally generated levels keep each run fresh and challenging. The wide variety of weapons, abilities, and mutations allows for endless experimentation and customization of your playstyle. Every death feels like a learning experience, encouraging you to tweak your strategy and dive back in for "just one more run."

The pixel art in Dead Cells is stunning, with each area meticulously designed and bursting with detail. The animations are smooth and responsive, making every dodge, slash, and jump feel satisfying. The atmospheric soundtrack perfectly complements the game's tone, enhancing the immersion and intensity of each encounter.

One of the standout features of Dead Cells is its progression system. Even though you start from scratch with each run, the permanent upgrades and unlockable abilities give you a sense of continual growth and improvement. This balance between roguelike challenge and rewarding progression keeps you coming back for more.

For a game that advocates all about caution and playing it slow, it sure has music that incentivizes people to do the exact opposite.

Jokes aside, a banger game, great variety of weapons, dope music, good 2d souls like combat. In terms of difficulty I do think its done quite well, unlike most roguelites where later playthroughs are easier, in this case they are harder. I did not get most references but its quite evident that the developers had a lot of passion for this game!

Some critisisms.
- 4-5 bc the damage received is quite ridiculous, 1 mistake costing u 80% of ur hp on 2-3rd biome, requiring u to do a mostly hitless run, which i'd say is quite a challenge for many.
- build diversity is quite limited, since some builds are by far superior.
- overabundance of interesting mutations, however only 3 slots per run. Truly missed potential. And that's not assuming you're not running some mutations every run due to playstyle / build options (no mercy / necromancy for me). Perhaps nerfing them a bit and allowing 4-5 could add a some of variety

probably a top metroidvania roguelite for most fans of the sub-genre. even with the attention it garnered meaning a lot of newer games followed some of the trends it set, it still feels unbeaten for many. i can't say that much in that regard, since in my case it's the game that really got me both into metroidvania structure and difficult (for me) action roguelites (tho i will say, the game is not [i]that[/i] heavy on the metroidvania, or roguelite mechanics. its the way its executed and combined many of the ones that are present, that it does more than enough to keep one engaged for many runs, and in my case even enjoy a type of hard (at least for me) combat that usually just frustrates me. 

also the pixel art is gorgeous, and i'm one of those that mentally rolls her eyes a lot of the times i see "another indie game with retro-inspired pixel art, etc etc" but the brilliant execution, paired with its unique aesthethic even within those constraints (tho inevitably imitated nowadays given how loved the game became) makes one remember why the style (pixel art) had a resurgence with some really great indie games. even on big monitors or TV's, it looks gorgeous, and the animations make it feel so much more responsive.

in regards to the game in general and the PC version in particular, the options and configurable variables etc are so great to see, and one of those things im glad to see becoming a bit more standardized now. on a similar note, has great accessibility options that don't just dumb down or make the game too easy. legit feel like accessibility options, as in to help those with specific issues. game is challenging but the game loop is rewarding enough that makes you wanna keep pushing, learning the game further, and unlocking powers and items and eventually difficulty options/modes, while feeling like you're improving at the game through multiple means.

aside from that, the devs are just really cool and i'll be interested in anything they release here onwards. there's also a whole list of games they released for free before this. they've been around for a minute but i'm so glad and happy for them that their first big commercial release has done so well. wishing them nothing but success and to continue to think their own way. so needed and such a great example for currently starting dev teams. i've no doubt their next game, and anything else they decide to add to this, will be nothing but the best the space has to offer.

tldr: [b]game is awesome, great introduction to its genre(s), while being challenging and engaging for many many runs and hours. there's really good reason the game has been praised and copied so much.[/b] one of those that, afaik, people deep in the games and media industries highly enjoy, recommend, and use as example to follow. can probably recommend to anyone even casually interested in these sorts of games

I first ever played this game in Early Access and it's come a long way since then. Extremely fun game with a lot of depth to it, lots of unique weapons and enemies and a really interesting world to explore full of secrets. It has a ton of replayability, being a roguelite, and lots of builds to try out, so there's something for everyone. Soundtrack is great, especially the Castlevania tracks, Combat is fast-paced and very roll-centered like certain other games (that too many games want to be like, imo) but it works for this game. Or, if you want to be more daring, parrying is also an option. I've been playing for a while now and still have more to see.

But, It also fell for the trap of deciding it needed to cater to tryhards with the endgame content. I can understand having difficulty levels, but a significant amount of unlocks and content is locked behind those and those suck the fun out of the game more and more with each level of it. I've been able to handle them, but it doesn't make it fun to play the game on them at all, it makes it a slog, like, doing perfectly for four stages then getting 1-shot by 4 enemies camping a platform kind of slog. There were a ton of ways to make it both difficult and fun but they went for the more difficult, less fun route. They do, to their credit, provide an assist mode that lets you configure everything about the game to make those difficulties easier, but I feel it should be fun to play to begin with, without needing to customize anything.

Basically, very fun game poisoned by extremely tryhard difficulty in endgame. Increasing the difficulty is fine, but you can do far better than what the endgame currently is, devs.

Recipe for Potato Dumplings (Varenyky)
Ingredients:
For the dough:
Wheat flour – 500 g
Water – 200 ml
Egg – 1
Salt – 1 tsp
For the filling:
Potatoes – 1 kg
Onions – 2
Lard or butter – 50 g
Salt – to taste
Ground black pepper – to taste
Preparation steps:
Making the dough:
Sifting the flour: Sift the flour into a large bowl.
Making the dough: Add salt and the egg to the flour. Gradually pour in the water, constantly stirring. Knead the dough until it becomes smooth and elastic.
Resting the dough: Wrap the dough in plastic wrap or cover it with a towel and let it rest for 30 minutes.
Preparing the filling:
Boiling the potatoes: Peel the potatoes, cut them into large pieces, and boil until tender in salted water.
Preparing the onions: While the potatoes are boiling, finely chop the onions. Sauté the onions in lard or butter until golden brown.
Making the potato puree: Drain the potatoes and mash them. Add the sautéed onions, salt, and pepper to taste, and mix well.
Forming the dumplings:
Rolling out the dough: Roll out the dough into a thin sheet about 2-3 mm thick. Use a glass or cutter to cut out circles approximately 7-8 cm in diameter.
Forming the dumplings: Place a spoonful of potato filling on each circle of dough. Fold the dough in half and pinch the edges tightly to seal the dumplings.
Cooking the dumplings:
Boiling water: Bring a large pot of water to a boil, add salt.
Cooking the dumplings: Gently drop the dumplings into the boiling water, stirring carefully to prevent sticking. Cook until done (approximately 5-7 minutes after they float to the surface).
Serving:
Removing the dumplings: Remove the dumplings with a slotted spoon and place them on a plate.
Serving: Serve the dumplings hot, optionally drizzling with melted butter, sour cream, or sautéed onions.
Enjoy your meal!

'Dead Cells' was my first experience in the world of roguelikes. Its blend of challenge and reward struck a perfect balance, keeping me engaged through every run.

Visually, Dead Cells is stunning. With its unique art style and character design, the gameplay experience was thoroughly enjoyable.

What sets it apart is the blend of both core roguelike mechanics with roguelite elements. The ability to spend resources at shops mid-run for permanent upgrades unlocks added levels of strategy without compromising the thrill of permadeath.

Adapting to the 2D platformer roguelike genre initially was quite challenging, but eventually each run became more and more rewarding. Buttery smooth combat, and countless weapon and spell combinations made fighting enemies enjoyable each time.

I feel that Dead Cells was an excellent introduction to the genre of roguelikes, but due to its repetitiveness and several areas blocked by DLC walls, isn't something I would see myself coming back to frequently.

The game is initially fun but then turns into a slog at higher difficulties.

Pros:
+initially fun
+cool art style
+accessibility features
+runs aren't too long
+good music

Cons:
-The game's idea of difficulty is dying in 3 or 4 hits
-bosses have damage caps at 15 percent making slow hitting weapons useless
-The game does not have much skill choice for a rogue like.  Scrolls choice turns into which of the three colors are you picking
-Platforming controls are awkward and have heavy punishment of losing life
-not encouraged to do multiple runs
-the game requires too many cells to unlock weapons and upgrades
-the game's idea of difficulty is just to remove all healing items so that you have to do an hour run wiht only getting hit a couple of times
-dodge roll has a weird delay after using it; the game does this so you cannot spam it; however they should have just removed some iframes at the end of the roll and let you roll once the stand up animation occurs
-feels like a waste of time when breezing through a run and get instakilled by a boss or cheap enemy
-the game isn't very rogue like without unlocking weapons.  There are limited weapons in the beginning so every run feels similar.
-unlocking multiple weapons makes the game worse by putting more bad ones in the pool; punished for unlocking weapons when you should look up a guide and only unlock the good ones
-the weapons feel too similar to use
-every run starts feeling the same of just going through a maze to collect 2 or 3 scrolls and some weapons.  The biomes do not introduce unique challenges on repeat playthrough

Dead Cells is a game I hadn't picked up for a long time, even despite being a huge fan of roguelikes, metroidvanias, and 2D adventure games; however, late is better than never for a game that has become an absolute staple across all the genres that come together to make Dead Cells. The branching pathways between levels is a great addition, as well as level-specific puzzles/gimmicks (some even multi-level) that added a fun spice to each run. Also, after each completion, the game opens up a little more each time, not only adding to replayability, but also ensuring you're not simply running through the same game over and over and over.

To put it into another perspective for prospective players:
If you gauge a game's success and quality off of how many cross-overs that OTHER metroidvania-roguelikes want to be in their game? Dead Cells has, like, 15 cross-over costumes and weapons; several of them with special effects or features, sometimes pushing the boundary of the art-style, but a testament, itself, to it's popularity and subsequent quality.

I played for 44 hours, with 2 completions, before I bought the ALL DLC (on sale, but not by much), and that's not something I do very often - if ever. There's very few games that make quality DLC, or deserve DLC, and Dead Cells is a stellar example that deserves both and more.

I have been playing Dead Cells for quite a while now.
From the moment you start, even your first ever run, the combat feels incredibly fluid, and pulling off combos and dodges is immensely satisfying, it immediately drew me in. The game grew with each update, and I loved it!
One of the things I love most is the game's sense of humor. There are little jokes and references scattered throughout and i enjoyed finding each one. 

Plus, the devs have done an amazing job with the DLCs. Each one adds new layers of depth and content, keeping the game fresh and engaging, I've especially enjoyed getting my ass handed to me in Dracula's castle. The beautiful art of this game is what motivated me to start doing pixel art myself, and that art gave me the ability to be able to own this game once more.

There's a ton of items, unique mechanics, bosses, enemies and character outfits alongside NPCs that give the game life, it feels immersive and the storytelling is done in a way that lets you discover it through each new room you loot, finding small notes and piecing it together. 

To anyone bored, in search of a challenge, or a new game to play, please play this masterpiece.

Welcome to Dead Cells, the game where dying is not just an inevitability but a rite of passage. This roguelike platformer throws you into a beautifully dark and pixelated world where every misstep, every missed dodge, and every overly ambitious leap into the unknown can spell your doom. But fear not, because in Dead Cells, death is merely a pit stop on your journey to mastering the art of hack, slash, and try not to get crushed by that giant rolling spike ball.

Graphically, Dead Cells is a feast for the eyes—if your idea of a feast involves dark dungeons, eerie forests, and enemies that look like they crawled out of Tim Burton's sketchbook. The pixel art style is not just nostalgic; it's a reminder that even in a world overrun by grotesque monsters and deadly traps, there's beauty in the darkness.

Gameplay is where Dead Cells shines brighter than a freshly polished broadsword. You'll start each run as a squishy, naked blob (no, really, you're a literal blob) and progressively morph into a formidable force of nature with a penchant for decimating enemies with everything from rusty swords to electrified whips. Combat is fluid, fast-paced, and as satisfying as landing a critical hit on that pesky boss who's killed you twelve times in a row.

Weapons and abilities in Dead Cells are as varied as they are absurd. From throwing out explosive barrels like confetti to summoning a swarm of carnivorous plants to do your bidding (because why not?), every run feels like a chaotic experiment in finding the perfect combination of gear and skills to survive just a little bit longer. And let's not forget the mutations—because who doesn't want to evolve into a fire-breathing, teleporting, grenade-launching monstrosity?

Playing Dead Cells is like riding a rollercoaster made of swords and death traps. Each level is procedurally generated, meaning you never quite know what's around the corner until you're impaled on it. And speaking of impalement, did I mention the traps? Spiked floors, swinging pendulums of doom, and the occasional pit of lava that makes you question your life choices—all strategically placed to remind you that in Dead Cells, caution is for the weak (and probably already dead).

But here's the kicker: death isn't the end in Dead Cells; it's a chance to regroup, strategize, and occasionally curse loudly when you realize you forgot to heal before stumbling into that boss fight again. Each death brings new unlocks, upgrades, and a renewed determination to finally conquer that one level that's become your personal nemesis.

In conclusion, Dead Cells isn't just a game; it's a pulse-pounding, adrenaline-fueled journey through a world where danger lurks around every corner and every victory is earned through blood, sweat, and occasionally throwing a kitchen sink at a swarm of undead. Whether you're a seasoned veteran of roguelikes or a newcomer eager to test your reflexes and patience, Dead Cells offers an experience that's as challenging as it is rewarding—and as funny as it is frustrating. So sharpen your blades, brace yourself for the unexpected, and prepare to die (a lot) in the most exhilarating way possible.

This is a good Rogue-lite. (let's be critical here)

I would not have bought it if it did not have the "metroidvania" tag. This is not a metroidvania. This is a Roguelike. This isn't an adventure game. It's an Action focused Hack-and-Slash that has a lot of things going for it. They just aren't things that I particularly like. If you're a purest - This is a Rogue-lite.

Animations are nice. Game has lots of "variety." *Most* of the enemies are engaging without being brick walls or action-killers. The level generation is well designed, and it's clear a lot of care went into how the levels generate themselves. Metroidvania type powers are unlocked that allow you to bypass areas, find new areas, and find hidden loot. Maybe more.

So, most of the "variety" I encountered in this game was surface level, and there was a tactic and combo of weapons that stuck out to me as "the best." This is why I dislike the genre, because there are a lot of cool synergies her, but if you don't get them before the first boss, just restart.

The game's difficulty curve is... bad. Really bad. This is either an easy game, or an impossible one. You either get what you need, or you don't make it past the second leg of the game, "Silt Village."
The lead up to SV and fisrt boss are extremely well done, fun, and engaging. The Village is a mess of overinflated numbers and new mechanics. The stages afterwards are laughably easy. The second boss is easy, but ok. After this point in the game, I no longer needed to spend money or pick up any new items.
The stages that follow are laughably easy, but longer, so you lose out on a lot of the action this game was good at. The boss that made me quit - "The King's Hand" is bad. Basically, because you can accumulate so much health/power before this fight, they had to just add cheesy mechanics to even it out.

In short, Dead Cells is a banger. Whether you're a casual gamer or a hardcore fan, it's got something for everyone. Don't sleep on it. 🕹️💀✨-Mr. GyatPT

Oh, Dead Cells, how I love this game! I can't put into words how much I adore it. I must have put in around 1500 hours or more in alternate ways. The difficulty, the feeling of dying and losing all your items and cells, starting over again—it's a massive frustration. But you always end up learning something each time you die. I wish I had the chance to pick it up on Steam ages ago, before I sunk countless hours into a 'Jack Sparrow' version of the game. Still, that didn't deter me from wanting to platinum the Steam version, which I'm currently working on. Those 1500+ hours were truly worth it, as I rarely die or take damage now. Now that I've shared my experience, you can buy it without hesitation; the fun is 100% guaranteed if this is your type of game. It's a solid 10/10 for the story, weapon variety, enemies—everything in this game fits together in perfect harmony. So, go ahead and buy it!

"Dead Cells" seamlessly blends roguelike and metroidvania genres into a fluid and dynamic action-platformer. With procedurally generated levels and a wide array of weapons and abilities, every playthrough offers a unique experience. If you're looking for a challenging yet rewarding game, "Dead Cells" is perfect for you!

Pros:

Fast and satisfying combat mechanics
High replayability with procedurally generated levels
Detailed pixel art graphics and impressive music

Cons:

High difficulty level may deter some players
Minimal story-telling

Rating: 10/10
